en: An image of the "Toot Sweet Express," a train in the Transportation Corps of the U.S. Army. The side graffiti reads "U.S.A. Bound. Germany to France. CP-BTRYS- "A" & "C". All Krants! No Chocolate. No Gum. No Cigarettes. No time. Howitzer Boys. High Pointers (70+). Going Home. Don't Delay! New York Chicago New Orleans (?) St. Louis. No Chow Either. Main 5520-13." The train's name was a play on the French phrase "tout de suite" (all at once). The train was a supply vessel which left Cherbourg every day for depots along the German border. The train ran on rail laid by the Allies in order to supply the front lines.
Era 8 - The Great Depression and World War II (1929-1945)

The train's name was a play on the French phrase "tout de suite" (all at once). The train was a supply vessel which left Cherbourg every day for depots along the German border. The train ran on rail laid by the Allies in order to supply the front lines.
University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
